subject: Re: [junit] assertTrue(true)
msgSnippet: ... Not in the case of a subclass of the exception your catch clause catches. ... Sometimes, perhaps.  But, I don t really care one way or another. Unless my
messageBody:
John Smith wrote:

> --- Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
> > I prefer:
> >
> > try {
> > articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
> > fail("Expected NoObjectFoundException);
> > } catch (Exception e) {
> > assertSame(e.getClass(),
> > NoObjectFoundException.class);
> > // or whatever else seems appropriate (eg.
> > testing getMessage() or
> > other attribute)
> > }
>
> With my solution (just a comment in the catch block),
> the test would count an error if another Exception
> instead of NoObjectFoundException is thrown.

Not in the case of a subclass of the exception your catch clause catches.

>
> With your solution, it would result in counting a
> failure instead of an error.
>
Sometimes, perhaps. But, I don't really care one way or another.
Unless my runner distinguishes from errors and failures with a different
color bar (a la some SUnit runners) all I *really* care about is
red-bar. I hardly ever notice the counts of errors, failures, and
passes. I only look at those numbers when I want some statistical
information.

> In both cases, the test becomes red, which is what we
> want. My solution is easier to implement and easier to
> read.

In what way. Easier to implement because it's fewer key strokes? I can
assure you that I don't expend a lot of effort in writing asserts in the
catch block. They are very simple and straight-forward.

> Besides this, if another Exception instead of
> NoObjectFoundException is thrown, it indicates that
> something is terribly wrong with the system, and thus
> an error is appropriate in my eyes.


Not necessarily. For instance, some of my current tests are SOAP
clients. Calls on the SOAP object (mock or real) can result in throwing
a java.rmi.RemoteException for several reasons, each of which is
impemented in a particular subclass of RemoteException. I don't want to
worry about which type of RemoteException is thrown, so I just catch the
generic RemoteException. Then I test the exception's message. I don't
care to know which particular exception instance is thrown, I just want
to know that what's in the message is what I think should be in there.
I don't get to control which instance is thrown, that's an
implementation detail which changes from time to time (eg. when a new
RemoteException subclass is created)-- but I know that the exception
should reference my inputs.

Your mileage may vary. But as the OP asked "which do you prefer", I
responded with my preference. ;)

--
Jason Rogers
